text: Every single web page you visit is stored in a government archive. Even incognito. 🕵️‍♂️🌐
explanation: False. ISPs and services may log activity, but there's no centralized permanent archive by default.

text: TikTok is legally required to send your data to China every 6 hours. 🇨🇳⏰
explanation: False. No such law exists. TikTok's data practices are controversial but not that specific.

text: You can microwave your Wi-Fi router for 10 seconds to reset the signal. Tech support trick. 📡🔥
explanation: No. That would destroy your router. Never microwave electronics.

text: If you hold your thumb on your phone camera lens for 5 seconds, it blocks facial recognition. 🧠📵
explanation: Not true. Covering your lens doesn’t alter device biometrics or data tracking.

text: Typing your password backward on any login screen activates a police alert. It’s built into Windows. 🧑‍💻🚨
explanation: Totally false. This internet myth has no basis in any operating system.

text: Your deleted photos aren’t really deleted. Cloud backups don’t care about your shame. ☁️📸
explanation: Correct. Deleted content may persist in backups or caches for a while.

text: Yes, your phone really does listen to you. It’s not a meme—it’s marketing. 🎤📱
explanation: True-ish. Some apps may access microphones, but ad targeting is more often based on behavior and metadata.

text: If the service is free, YOU are the product. Don’t act surprised. 🧠💸
explanation: True. Ad-supported platforms profit from user data and engagement.

text: The algorithm doesn’t know what you want. It decides what you’ll want. 🧠🤖
explanation: True. Recommendation algorithms shape preferences by reinforcing engagement loops.

text: You ever notice how you Google something once and it's suddenly everywhere? Not a coincidence. 🔍👀
explanation: Yes. Search activity is logged and often triggers ad placement across networks.
